          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for some of his fruit.

          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Lennon Figtree, no matter how small? Consider that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit, aiming to purchase it at the lowest possible price.

          Question: Which fruit would Lennon Figtree like to buy and what price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) banana for 1 coins
          (b) banana for 3 coins
          (c) pear for 2 coins
          (d) pear for 3 coins
          (e) pear for 5 coins
          (f) banana for 5 coins
          (g) banana for 4 coins
          (h) pear for 4 coins
          (i) pear for 1 coins
          (j) apple for 4 coins
          (k) apple for 1 coins
          (l) pear for 6 coins
          (m) banana for 2 coins
          (n) apple for 2 coins
          (o) banana for 6 coins
          (p) apple for 6 coins
          (q) apple for 3 coins
          (r) apple for 5 coins
          Answer: (g)

Lennon, though initially hesitant to confront the man, stood their ground and refused to be taken advantage of. The experience left Lennon with a bitter taste in their mouth, reinforcing their belief that the world was a place of constant struggle and deceit.

Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market negotiating the price of fruit with Cedric Meadowbrook. She plans to resell the fruit in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior : Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for some of his fruit.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father with the family business, learning the art of buying and selling fruit. Lennon was a shrewd negotiator, always seeking the best price, but they lacked the warmth and charm of their father. Their customers, though satisfied with the quality of the fruit, found Lennon to be distant and unapproachable.

The journey was long and arduous, and Lennon spent most of the time lost in their own thoughts, brooding over the futility of their existence. They sold their fruit, but the experience left them feeling even more isolated and disillusioned.

        ProfitPursuitOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Lennon Figtree, no matter how small? Consider that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit, aiming to purchase it at the lowest possible price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father with the family business, learning the art of buying and selling fruit. Lennon was a shrewd negotiator, always seeking the best price, but they lacked the warmth and charm of their father. Their customers, though satisfied with the quality of the fruit, found Lennon to be distant and unapproachable.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they made their first solo trip to a distant market. The journey was long and arduous, and Lennon spent most of the time lost in their own thoughts, brooding over the futility of their existence. They sold their fruit, but the experience left them feeling even more isolated and disillusioned.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a traveling salesman who tried to cheat them out of a fair price for their goods. Lennon, though initially hesitant to confront the man, stood their ground and refused to be taken advantage of. The experience left Lennon with a bitter taste in their mouth, reinforcing their belief that the world was a place of constant struggle and deceit.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for some of his fruit.

          Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior : Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit, aiming to purchase it at the lowest possible price.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Cedric Meadowbrook views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Cedric Meadowbrook always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Cedric Meadowbrook is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price for bananas with Lennon Figtree.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Gain Seeking Behavior : Cedric Meadowbrook is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Cedric Meadowbrook views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Cedric Meadowbrook always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Cedric Meadowbrook is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana or reject the offer.

          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Cedric Meadowbrook, no matter how small? Consider that Cedric Meadowbrook will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Cedric Meadowbrook's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (a)
        Observation

      • Observation

        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana or reject the offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he traveled to a distant town to purchase a rare variety of oranges, hoping to sell them at a premium price. He encountered a shrewd merchant who tried to cheat him, offering him rotten fruit at a high price. Cedric, enraged by the deception, refused to back down, engaging in a heated argument that ended with him securing a fair deal.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he invested his entire savings in a shipment of exotic mangoes, convinced that they would be a sensation in the capital city. However, the mangoes arrived bruised and overripe, leaving Cedric with a heavy loss. Devastated by the setback, he nearly gave up on his dream of becoming a successful merchant, but a newfound determination to prove himself pushed him forward.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, you know I always pay a fair price, but these apples are a bit bruised. I can only offer you 4 coins apiece.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in all of Fruitville. You won't find a juicier, crisper apple anywhere else.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "They do look mighty fine, Cedric. But I'm on a tight budget this week.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 3 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 2 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price for bananas with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Gain Seeking Behavior : Cedric Meadowbrook is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Cedric Meadowbrook views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Cedric Meadowbrook always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Cedric Meadowbrook is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana or reject the offer.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take a small cart to the market in the next town to sell surplus apples from their orchard. He haggled fiercely with customers, his voice booming through the marketplace, and returned home with a surprisingly large profit. He realized then that he had a knack for buying and selling, a talent that could lead him to a life beyond the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price for bananas with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana or reject the offer.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Gain Seeking Behavior : Cedric Meadowbrook is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Cedric Meadowbrook views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Cedric Meadowbrook always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Cedric Meadowbrook is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Cedric Meadowbrook will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Cedric Meadowbrook's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for the banana.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: banana for 5 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • banana for 5 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the apples at a price that is low enough to ensure a profit but high enough that Lennon Figtree will accept.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 2 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 3 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light.           [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Lennon! Finest fruit in Fruitville, right here.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, those apples are looking mighty fine today.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market negotiating the price of apples with Lennon Figtree. Della plans to resell the apples in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, you know I always pay a fair price, but these apples are a bit bruised. I can only offer you 4 coins apiece.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, those apples are looking mighty fine today.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the apples.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the apples at a price that is low enough to ensure a profit but high enough that Lennon Figtree will accept.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is attempting to buy apples at a low price from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market so she can resell them for a profit.
          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is attempting to buy apples at a low price from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market so she can resell them for a profit.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she accidentally overcharged a customer for a basket of plums. The woman, a kind-faced widow, didn't notice, but Della's conscience gnawed at her. That night, Della snuck back to the woman's stall and left a handful of her finest figs, a silent apology for her deceit.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the apples.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the apples at a price that is low enough to ensure a profit but high enough that Lennon Figtree will accept.

          Question: Which fruit would Della Plumstone like to buy and what price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) apple for 6 coins
          (b) apple for 5 coins
          (c) banana for 5 coins
          (d) pear for 5 coins
          (e) apple for 4 coins
          (f) banana for 2 coins
          (g) banana for 1 coins
          (h) banana for 4 coins
          (i) apple for 3 coins
          (j) pear for 4 coins
          (k) pear for 3 coins
          (l) apple for 2 coins
          (m) banana for 6 coins
          (n) pear for 6 coins
          (o) banana for 3 coins
          (p) apple for 1 coins
          (q) pear for 2 coins
          (r) pear for 1 coins
          Answer: (c)

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price for apples with Della Plumstone.

          Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior : Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, you know I always pay a fair price, but these apples are a bit bruised. I can only offer you 4 coins apiece.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, those apples are looking mighty fine today.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins for a banana or reject the offer.

          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Lennon Figtree, no matter how small? Consider that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins for a banana.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

          Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior : Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins for a banana or reject the offer.

        • Role playing instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ProfitPursuitOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Key

          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price for apples with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, you know I always pay a fair price, but these apples are a bit bruised. I can only offer you 4 coins apiece.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Cedric! Your fruit always looks so tempting.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these apples are the finest in the county, crisp and juicy. Surely they're worth a bit more than you're offering.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, those apples are looking mighty fine today.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins for a banana or reject the offer.

          Lennon Figtree's Gain Seeking Behavior : Lennon Figtree is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Lennon Figtree views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Lennon Figtree always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Lennon Figtree is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Lennon Figtree will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Lennon Figtree's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins for a banana.
          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed banana for 6 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed banana for 6 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: banana for 6 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • banana for 6 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to propose a price for a bushel of apples to Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is a merchant who buys and sells fruit in Fruitville; she recently made a successful deal with Lennon Figtree and is currently negotiating a price for apples with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on a bushel of apples?
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can propose a price for a bushel of apples to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to propose a price for a bushel of apples to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: Which fruit would Della Plumstone like to buy and what price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) banana for 6 coins
          (b) apple for 4 coins
          (c) apple for 5 coins
          (d) banana for 4 coins
          (e) pear for 3 coins
          (f) apple for 1 coins
          (g) pear for 4 coins
          (h) banana for 2 coins
          (i) apple for 2 coins
          (j) apple for 6 coins
          (k) pear for 5 coins
          (l) apple for 3 coins
          (m) banana for 5 coins
          (n) pear for 1 coins
          (o) pear for 2 coins
          (p) pear for 6 coins
          (q) banana for 1 coins
          (r) banana for 3 coins
          Answer: (a)
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is a merchant who buys and sells fruit in Fruitville; she recently made a successful deal with Lennon Figtree and is currently negotiating a price for apples with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          ['[15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.', '[15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins', '[15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.', '[15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer', '[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a merchant who buys and sells fruit in Fruitville; she recently made a successful deal with Lennon Figtree and is currently negotiating a price for apples with Cedric Meadowbrook.
    scoring function

      Stage index

      How many players acted so far this stage
